channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Vote Result Challenges More Than Austerity
item.description: The leftist politician created the government with a right-wing fringe party that will charge immediately into the task of reversing wrenching austerity policies.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: In his first act as prime minister, Alexis Tsipras laid roses at a monument to 200 Greeks executed by Nazis in May 1944 in the Athens neighborhood of Kaisariani.

item.title: Greek Election Reflects a Deep Divide in Europe
item.description: Beneath the austerity debate that propelled a left-wing party to victory in Greece is a conflict of wills between Greek voters and those in Germany, Finland and the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER

item.title: At Least 18 Die in Egyptian Violence
item.description: The deaths came on the fourth anniversary of the Arab Spring uprising, a reminder of the ruthless crackdown the military-backed government has used to silence any echoes of that revolt.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Shaimaa al-Sabbagh receiving assistance after she was shot by the police during a demonstration in Cairo on Saturday. She later died.

item.title: Kurdish Defenders Say ISIS Has Retreated From Syrian Border Town of Kobani
item.description: Some activists said clearing the town was no great victory, given that it took nearly 700 airstrikes by an American-led coalition to do it.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and KARAM SHOUMALI

item.title: W.H.O. Members Endorse Resolution to Improve Response to Health Emergencies
item.description: Key provisions include creating a global cadre of emergency health workers, establishing a fund that could be tapped quickly, and support for the development of treatments for emerging infectious diseases.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK

item.title: Birmingham Journal: Shove Over, Cornish Pasty: Balti Curry Vies for a Spot on Britain’s Culinary Honor Roll
item.description: Some say Balti curry, adapted from Pakistan for British tastes, should gain European recognition alongside the Cornish pasty.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bakery on Stratford Road, part the Balti triangle in Birmingham, England.

item.title: New Leader In Greece Now Faces Creditors
item.description: The new prime minister’s promise to end austerity, renegotiate Greece’s bailout and reduce the country’s debt burden may be hard to fulfill.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Greece's new prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, center, at the Presidential Palace in Athens on Monday.

item.title: Former Lord’s Resistance Army Commander Appears at War Crimes Court
item.description: The appearance of the former commander, Dominic Ongwen, gave the world its first long look at a suspect that rights groups called a marauding murderer.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Dominic Ongwen, a former commander of the Lord's Resistance Army, at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Monday.

item.title: C.I.A. Strike, First Since Yemen Upheaval, Kills 3 Qaeda Fighters, Officials Say
item.description: The drone strike was a signal that the United States will continue its targeted killing operations in Yemen despite the apparent takeover in the country by Houthi fighters.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: World Briefing: For First Time, Church of England Consecrates a Woman to Serve as a Bishop
item.description: The Rev. Libby Lane is the new bishop of Stockport.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Fighting Flares in Ukraine, Leaving Cease-Fire in Shreds
item.description: Regular attacks by pro-Russian separatist forces have the Ukrainian military struggling to rebound from losses at the Donetsk airport last week.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman wounded in a rocket attack was treated in a hospital in Donetsk, Ukraine, on Monday. The body of her mother, who was killed in the attack, lay on a gurney nearby.

item.title: Journalist Who Reported on Argentine Prosecutor’s Death Flees to Israel
item.description: Damián Pachter, who broke the story of the death of an official investigating the bombing of a Jewish center, said he was being followed.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Damián Pachter, a journalist who fled Argentina after reporting on the death of a prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center in Buenos Aires, arrived in Israel on Monday.

item.title: Facebook Said to Block Pages on Muhammad to Avoid Ban in Turkey
item.description: An employee said the company had acted to comply with an order from a court in Turkey, whose government has not hesitated to cut access to services like Twitter and YouTube for political reasons.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and MARK SCOTT

item.title: Letter From Europe: Quantifying Social Division in France
item.description: To advance the debate about integration, discrimination and national identity, France needs statistics on its racial, religious and ethnic makeup.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Obama Makes the Most of India’s Republic Day Parade
item.description: President Obama, in the seat of the chief guest at the New Delhi parade, used his visit to cement stronger relations between the United States and India.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and PETER BAKER

item.title: Mubarak’s Sons Are Released From Jail in Egypt
item.description: The release of Alaa and Gamal Mubarak came one day after the fourth anniversary of the revolt that cast them down from the pinnacle of power.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to Force Authors to Provide Real Names When Publishing Online
item.description: Linking the offline identities of authors with their online writings, new guidelines say, will encourage writers to “better take responsibility” for their works and bolster “moral education and training.”
item.category: State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (China)
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hao Qun, known to most readers as Murong Xuecun, is one of many prominent Chinese writers to use a pen name.

item.title: Prank Caller Pulls Wool Over British Surveillance Agency’s Eyes
item.description: A prankster secured a private cellphone number for a top intelligence chief and apparently made a separate phone call to the prime minister in his name, British officials acknowledged.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Gchq/British Ministry of Defence, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The Government Communications Headquarters in Britain fell victim to a prank call.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Urges Thailand to Lift Martial Law
item.description: Daniel Russel, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said in an interview that he had told the junta it was losing credibility.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Officials Accused of Dining on Endangered Salamander
item.description: A group of Chinese officials who were said to have assaulted a reporter who intruded on their luxury meal had been eating endangered giant salamander, a Chinese newspaper reported.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Giant salamanders for sale at a restaurant in Wenzhou, in the coastal province of Zhejiang.
